subject: Law
title: Executive Orders and Their Limits
description: A quick, practical guide to Executive Orders and Their Limits.

hook.text: Lincoln freed enslaved people with a stroke of his pen. Roosevelt interned 120,000 Japanese Americans with another.

buildup.text: Executive orders let presidents direct federal operations without waiting for Congress to pass a law.

discovery.text: They carry the force of law but must be grounded in constitutional or statutory authority.

twist.text: Courts can strike them down. Truman tried to seize steel mills in 1952. The Supreme Court stopped him cold.

climax.text: Youngstown Sheet & Tube v. Sawyer set the framework: presidential power is weakest when Congress says no.

punchline.text: A president's pen is powerful, but not unlimited.

quiz.question: Which case limited presidential seizure power?
